A restart/some updates

Apr 2, 2024

I used to post relatively frequently on this blog as an undergraduate, and essentially stopped once I started grad school. It seems fun to try to restart it (and post with far less frequency than I used to). (I have archived the old posts; if, for some reason, you want to see them, let me know.) In this post, I want to talk about a recent article that I finished. It is concerned with a few different, but related, topics, and I would like to illustrate some of them in the next few posts. In this one, I will focus on the results concerned with “ordinary coefficients” (i.e., no complex K-theory, etc.), and so I will phrase the discussion so as to try to appeal to algebraic topologists.

The basic question at hand is the following. Suppose is a complex reductive group, always assumed connected, and let denote its Langlands dual group. This is the split reductive group over (and over , if one wants; I will try to address integrality questions later) whose root datum is dual to the root datum of . That such a thing even exists is an absolute miracle! One of the things learned from number theory/geometric representation theory is that the topology/harmonic analysis of is described by the algebraic geometry of the Langlands dual group. It is good to keep examples in mind, so here are a few important ones. If is a torus with character lattice , then is the dual torus with character lattice . If is , then also; if is , then ; if , then .

Number theorists are often interested, among many other things, in geometry/harmonic analysis on symmetric spaces like , where is a maximal compact subgroup of . For instance, if , then , and the quotient is the upper half-plane. The theory of modular forms falls into the realm of harmonic analysis on this quotient. One can geometrize this picture: this amounts to replacing the local field by with being a finite field, and the maximal compact subgroup by . Now, functions on can, by the sheaf-function dictionary, be viewed as arising via the trace of Frobenius acting on (the cohomology of) a sheaf on . Moreover, since “all algebraically closed fields have the same geometry”, we may as well replace by the complex numbers . The quotient is called the affine Grassmannian and denoted , and it plays a crucial role in geometric representation theory.

One of the most important results in setting up the Langlands program is the Satake isomorphism, which is concerned with the algebra of (-valued, say) functions on , made into an algebra via convolution. The theorem is that this algebra is isomorphic to the Grothendieck group of the category of representations of the dual group base-changed to .

By our discussion in the preceding paragraph, one can hope that this might be categorified/geometrized: one can instead study the category of sheaves on the double coset space . The Satake isomorphism mentioned above admits a categorification. Namely, it turns out that there is a t-structure on whose heart identifies with the abelian category . This is known as the geometric Satake equivalence, proved by Mirkovic and Vilonen. This theorem has a rather remarkable consequence in pure homotopy theory, and this is what I would like to explain in an example.

If is any space, taking the global sections of a sheaf on defines a functor to the category of comodules over the cocommutative coalgebra of chains on . This works equivariantly, too: namely, if denotes the coalgebra of equivariant chains on , taking global sections defines a functor . The geometric Satake equivalence and the Tannakian formalism together give a map

of coalgebras over . It is not hard to see that there is a homotopy equivalence . A theorem of Quillen’s also gives a homotopy equivalence , where is the based loop space of . Moreover, the action of on is homotopy equivalent to the conjugation action of on . So the preceding map can simply be identified as a map of coalgebras

One interesting observation, which I studied in this article, is that this map can in fact be defined even with ordinary cohomology replaced by connective complex K-theory and elliptic cohomology (at least if is simply-laced and semisimple). But more on that later.

The question at hand is: what is this map explicitly? I will describe what it does on homotopy in some examples, where it connects to a lot of classical and beautiful homotopy theory. It is convenient to note that is actually an -ring, which in particular means that is a graded-commutative ring. Moreover, if denotes the Lie algebra of the torus of and denotes the Weyl group, there is an isomorphism . We can therefore think of the map of interest as a homomorphism

of group schemes over .

I will focus mostly on the case , just to keep the discussion light. (Also, the map we are interested in is defined even before Borel-completion, so I will not do a Borel-completion anywhere below.) In this case, with the Weyl group acting by permutation. Therefore again, where the coordinates are given by the elementary symmetric polynomials . When identified with , the generator lives in .

So, what is ?
